sen.j: 吉野水分神社（よしのみくまりじんじゃ）は奈良県吉野郡吉野町子守地区（吉野山上千本）にある神社である。
sen.e: Yoshinomikumari-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in the Komori district of Yoshino Town, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture (Mt. Yoshino-yama Kami-senbon).
Yoshinomikumari-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in the Komori district of Yoshino Town, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture (Mt. Yoshino-yama Kami-senbon).
Yoshino Mikumari-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in the Komori district of Yoshino-cho, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture (Mt. Yoshino Kami-senbon).

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は村社。
sen.e: It is a shikinaisha (Shinto shrine listed in the Engishiki) and a village shrine in the old shrine ranking.
It is a shikinaisha (Shinto shrine listed in the Engishiki) and a village shrine in the old shrine ranking.
It is a shikinaisha (Shinto shrine listed in the Engishiki) and a sonsha (village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.

sen.j: 葛城水分神社・都祁水分神社・宇太水分神社とともに大和国四所水分社の一つとして古くから信仰されてきた。
sen.e: As one of the four Mikumari-jinja Shrines of the Yamato Province along with Katsuragi Mikumari-jinja Shrine, Tsugemikumari-jinja Shrine and Udamikumari-jinja Shrine, it has been worshipped for a very long time.

As one of the four Mikumari-jinja Shrines of the Yamato Province along with Katsuragi Mikumari-jinja Shrine, Tsugemikumari-jinja Shrine and Udamikumari-jinja Shrine, it has been worshiped for a very long time.

As one of the four Mikumari-jinja Shrines of the Yamato Province along with Katsuragi Mikumari-jinja Shrine, Tsuge Mikumari-jinja Shrine and Uda Mikumari-jinja Shrine, it has been worshiped for a very long time.
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、Tsuge Mikumari-jinja Shrine、Uda Mikumari-jinja Shrineとしました。

sen.j: また、「みくまり」が「みこもり」となまり、子守明神と呼ばれ子授けの神として信仰を集めている。
sen.e: Also, 'Mikumari' sounds like 'Mikomori' (to be with child), causing it to be called the Komori Myojin (deity of pregnancy) and attracting worship as the god of pregnancy.
Also, 'Mikumari' sounds like 'Mikomori' (to be with child), causing it to be called the Komori Myojin (deity of pregnancy) and attracting worship as the god of pregnancy.
Also, 'Mikumari' sounds like 'Mikomori' (to be with child), causing it to be called the Komori Myojin (deity of pregnancy) and attracting worship as the god of pregnancy.

sen.j: 宣長の両親の子守明神への祈願により本居宣長が授けられたといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that Norinaga MOTOORI's parents prayed to the Komori Myojin and were subsequently blessed.
It is said that Norinaga MOTOORI's parents prayed to the Komori Myojin and were subsequently blessed.
It is said that Norinaga MOTOORI's parents prayed to the Komori Myojin and were subsequently blessed.

sen.j: 2004年7月に、国際連合教育科学文化機関の世界遺産『紀伊山地の霊場と参詣道』の一部として登録された。
sen.e: In July 2004 it was registered as part of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) world heritage "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range."
In July 2004 it was registered as part of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) world heritage "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range."
In July 2004 it was registered as part of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) world heritage "Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range."
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正しました。

sen.j: 水を司る水分神（あめのみくまりのおおかみ）を主祭神とし、タカミムスビ・スクナビコナ・御子神・ニニギ・タマヨリビメ・栲幡千千姫命を配祀する。
sen.e: Amenomikumari-no-Okami who rules water is the main deity, and other associated gods that are enshrined are Takamimusubi, Sukunabikona, Mikogami, Ninigi, Tamayoribime and Takuhatachijihime-no-Mikoto.
Amenomikumari-no-Okami who rules water is the main deity, and other associated gods that are enshrined are Takamimusubi, Sukunabikona, Mikogami, Ninigi, Tamayoribime and Takuhatachijihime-no-Mikoto.

Ame no Mikumari no Okami who rules water is the main deity, and other associated gods that are enshrined are Takamimusubi, Sukunabikona, Mikogami, Ninigi, Tamayoribime and Takuhatachijihime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: Ame no Mikumari no Okami、Takuhatachijihime no Mikotoとしました。

sen.j: 『神社要録』では「天水分神・国水分神」、『神名帳考証』『大和国大小諸神社神名記並縁起』では単に「水神」と記されている。
sen.e: The "Jinja Yoroku" (Main Records of Shrines) refers to Amenomikumari-no-Okami as a god that controls the distribution of water such as water sources and river routes as well as rain, while in "Jinmyocho Kosho" (Historical Back of Jinmyocho) and "Yamatokoku Daisho Shojinja Shinmyoki narabini Engi" he is simply referred to as the god of water.

The "Jinja Yoroku" (Main Records of Shrines) refers to Amenomikumari-no-Okami as a god that controls the distribution of water such as water sources and river routes as well as rain, while in "Jinmyocho Kosho" (Historical Back of Jinmyocho) and "Yamatokoku Daisho Shojinja Shinmyoki narabini Engi" he is simply referred to as the god of water.

The "Jinja Yoroku" (Main Records of Shrines) refers to Ame no Mikumari no Okami as a god that controls the distribution of water such as water sources and river routes as well as rain, while in the "Jinmyocho Kosho" (Historical Back of Jinmyocho) and the "Yamatokoku Daisho Shojinja Shinmyoki narabini Engi" he is simply referred to as the god of water.
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、Ame no Mikumari no Okami、the "Jinmyocho Kosho"、the "Yamatokoku Daisho Shojinja Shinmyoki narabini Engi" としました。

sen.j: 創建については不詳である。
sen.e: Details surrounding the founding are unknown.
Details surrounding the founding are unknown.
Details surrounding the founding are unknown.

sen.j: 当社に関する最も古い記録は、『続日本紀』の文武天皇2年（698年）4月29日条で、芳野水分峰神に馬を奉り祈雨したとの記述である。
sen.e: The oldest record regarding this shrine is the April 29, 698 listing in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued), where it states that a horse was offered to the Yoshino Mikumari no Mine no Kami (Yoshino god of water distribution) to ask for rain.

The oldest record regarding this shrine is the April 29, 698, listing in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued), where it states that a horse was offered to the Yoshino Mikumari no Mine no Kami (Yoshino god of water distribution) to ask for rain.

The oldest record regarding this shrine is the April 29, 698, listing in the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued), where it states that a horse was offered to the Yoshino Mikumari no Mine no Kami (Yoshino god of water distribution) to ask for rain.
sen.cmt: 旧暦→新暦に修正→本の中に実際に記載されている日にちなので元に戻しました。in “Shoku Nihongi”→in the "Shoku Nihongi"としました。

sen.j: 当神社は、元来は吉野山の最奥部、吉野町、黒滝村、川上村 (奈良県)の境に位置する青根ヶ岳に位置したとされる。
sen.e: This shrine is said to have originally been located in the deepest area of Mt. Yoshino-yama at the border of Yoshino Town, Kurotaki Village and Kawakami Town (Nara Prefecture) where Mt. Aone-ga-take is.

This shrine is said to have originally been located in the deepest area of Mt. Yoshino-yama at the border of Yoshino Town, Kurotaki Village and Kawakami Town (Nara Prefecture) where Mt. Aone-ga-take is.
This shrine is said to have originally been located in the deepest area of Mt. Yoshino at the border of Yoshino-cho, Kurotaki-mura and Kawakami-mura (Nara Prefecture) where Mt. Aonegatake is.
sen.cmt: Mt. Yoshino-yama→Mt.Yoshino、Yoshino Town→Yoshino-cho、Kurotaki Village→Kurotaki-mura、Kawakami Town→Kawakami-mura、Mt. Aone-ga-take→Mt. Aonegatakeとしました。

sen.j: 青根ヶ岳は吉野川の支流である喜佐谷川が東へ、秋野川が西へ、音無川が北へ流れるなどの源流となる山で「水分 水配り」の神の鎮座地にふさわしい。
sen.e: Mt. Aone-ga-take is the mountain providing the source for three rivers - Kisaya River which is a branch of Yoshino River that flows to the east, Akino River which flows to the west and Otonashi River which flows to the north - making it a suitable place for the god of moisture and water distribution to be enshrined.

Mt. Aone-ga-take is the mountain providing the source for three rivers - Kisaya River which is a branch of Yoshino River that flows to the east, Akino River which flows to the west and Otonashi River which flows to the north - making it a suitable place for the god of moisture and water distribution to be enshrined.

Mt. Aonegatake is the mountain providing the source for three rivers - Kisaya-gawa River which is a branch of Yoshino-gawa River that flows to the east, Akino-gawa River which flows to the west and Otonashi-gawa River which flows to the north - making it a suitable place for the god of moisture and water distribution to be enshrined.
sen.cmt: Mt. Aonegatake、Kisaya-gawa River、Yoshino-gawa River、Akino-gawa River、Otonashi-gawa Riverとしました。

sen.j: 大同 (日本)元年（806年）ごろに現在地へ遷座した。
sen.e: It was relocated to its current location around the year 806.
It was relocated to its current location around the year 806.
It was relocated to its current location around the year 806.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では「大和国吉野郡 吉野水分神社」として記載され、大社に列し、月次・新嘗の幣帛に預ると記されている。
sen.e: In the Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan) it is recorded as 'Yamato Province Yoshino Region Yoshino Mikumari-jinja Shrine'; belonging to a Grand Shrine, it received heihaku (a sacramental strip of silk offered to gods) at monthly Niiname rites.

In the Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan) it is recorded as 'Yamato Province Yoshino Region Yoshino Mikumari-jinja Shrine'; belonging to a Grand Shrine, it received heihaku (a sacramental strip of silk offered to gods) at monthly Niiname rites.

In the Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan) it is recorded as 'Yamato Province Yoshino County Yoshino Mikumari-jinja Shrine'; belonging to a Grand Shrine, it received heihaku (a sacramental strip of silk offered to gods) at monthly and Niiname rites.
sen.cmt: 統一事項より、Yoshino Region→Yoshino Countyに修正、monthly Niiname rites→monthly and Niiname ritesとしました。

sen.j: 前防家が社家。
sen.e: Belongs to the MAEBO family.
sen.cmt: No reliable source for the pronunciation of the name was available.
sen.e: Belongs to the MAEBO family.
Belongs to the Maebo family (前防家).
sen.cmt: MAEBO family→Maebo familyとし、読み方不明のため漢字表記追加しました。

sen.j: 平安時代中期ごろから「子守明神」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Started to be called 'Komori Myojin' during the mid-Heian period.
Started to be called 'Komori Myojin' during the mid-Heian period.
Started to be called 'Komori Myojin' during the mid-Heian period.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉もこの地を訪れ豊臣秀頼を授かったといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI came to this land and was blessed with his son Hideyori TOYOTOMI.
It is said that Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI came to this land and was blessed with his son Hideyori TOYOTOMI.
It is said that Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI came to this land and was blessed with his son Hideyori TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 現在の社殿は慶長10年（1605年）に秀頼によって創建されたものである。
sen.e: The current sanctuary (main building) was built by Hideyori in 1605.
The current sanctuary (main building) was built by Hideyori in 1605.
The current sanctuary (main building) was built by Hideyori in 1605.

sen.j: 神仏習合時代には、水分神は地蔵菩薩の垂迹とされ、金峰山の蔵王権現（金峯山寺）に属する神社として修験道の行場の一つとなっていた。
sen.e: During the period of syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism it was said that the water god was a manifestation of Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha), and became a shrine belonging to Zao Gongen of Mt. Kinpusen (Kinpusen-ji Temple) and one of the training grounds for Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

During the period of syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism it was said that the water god was a manifestation of Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha), and became a shrine belonging to Zao Gongen of Mt. Kinpusen (Kinpusen-ji Temple) and one of the training grounds for Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

During the period of syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism it was said that the water god was a manifestation of Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha), and became a shrine belonging to Zao Gongen of Mt. Kinpusen (Kinpusen-ji Temple) and one of the training grounds for Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

sen.j: 明治の神仏分離によって金峯山寺より独立し、村社に列格した。
sen.e: During the separation of Shinto and Buddhism in the Meiji period it became independent of Kinpusen-ji Temple and was ranked a village shrine.
During the separation of Shinto and Buddhism in the Meiji period it became independent of Kinpusen-ji Temple and was ranked a village shrine.
During the separation of Shinto and Buddhism in the Meiji period it became independent of Kinpusen-ji Temple and was ranked a village shrine.

sen.j: 木造玉依姫命（たまよりひめのみこと）坐像－鎌倉時代の作。
sen.e: Wooden sitting statue of Tamayorihime no Mikoto – Kamakura period.
Wooden sitting statue of Tamayorihime no Mikoto – Kamakura period.
Wooden seated statue of Tamayorihime no Mikoto – Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 坐像→統一リストの表記に修正しました。

sen.j: 絵巻に描かれている女性の姿を彫刻に再現したかと思わせる女神像である。
sen.e: A statue of a goddess that gives the feeling that the figure of a woman in a picture scroll was recreated as sculpture.
A statue of a goddess that gives the feeling that the figure of a woman in a picture scroll was recreated as sculpture.
A statue of a goddess that gives the feeling that the figure of a woman in a picture scroll was recreated as sculpture.

sen.j: 日本の神像彫刻には素朴な作風のものが多い中で、本作品は玉眼（眼の部分に水晶を嵌め込む技法）を採用した本格的な彫刻である。
sen.e: While most Japanese sculptures of deities can be quite unsophisticated, this work of sculpture was very lifelike and incorporated the use of gyokugan (method where crystal pieces are used for the eyes).

While most Japanese sculptures of deities can be quite unsophisticated, this work of sculpture was very lifelike and incorporated the use of gyokugan (method where crystal pieces are used for the eyes).

While most Japanese sculptures of deities can be quite unsophisticated, this work of sculpture was very lifelike and incorporated the use of gyokugan (method where crystal pieces are used for the eyes).

sen.j: 像内に建長3年（1251年）の銘がある。
sen.e: The inside of the statue is inscribed with the year 1251.
The inside of the statue is inscribed with the year 1251.
The inside of the statue is inscribed with the year 1251.

sen.j: 本殿の右殿（向かって左）に安置される。
sen.e: It is stored in the right hall of the main building (to the left when facing the building).
It is stored in the right hall of the main building (to the left when facing the building).
It is stored in the right hall of the main building (to the left when facing the building).

sen.j: 神社の神体であるため、一般には公開されず、展覧会等に出品された記録もない。
sen.e: Because it is a sacred object belonging to the shrine, it is not displayed to the public and there is no record of it being shown in any exhibition or such.
Because it is a sacred object belonging to the shrine, it is not displayed to the public and there is no record of it being shown in any exhibition.
Because it is a sacred object belonging to the shrine, it is not displayed to the public and there is no record of it being shown in any exhibition.

sen.j: 社殿（6棟）－各慶長10年（1605年）建造。
sen.e: Main building (building 6) – built in 1605.
sen.cmt: Use of 6棟 was unclear - whether it was to describe "six buildings" or "builing number six."
sen.e: Main building (building 6) – built in 1605.
Six shrine buildings – built in 1605.
sen.cmt: ここでは「6棟」ある「社殿」という意味と思われるため、Main building (building 6)→Six shrine buidingsに修正しました。

sen.j: 豊臣秀頼の創建。
sen.e: Built by Hideyori TOYOTOMI.
Built by Hideyori TOYOTOMI.
Built by Hideyori TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 楼門
sen.e: Tower Gate
Tower Gate
Tower Gate

sen.j: 本殿－正面の3箇所に破風があり、中央に春日造、左右に流造の三殿を横に繋げた形の特異な形式になる。
sen.e: Main hall – A very unique style with three gables at the front and three halls in a row, the middle hall built in Kasuga-zukuri style and the remaining two in Nagare-zukuri style
Main hall – A very unique style with three gables at the front and three halls in a row, the middle hall built in Kasuga-zukuri style and the remaining two in Nagare-zukuri style
Main hall – A very unique style with three gables at the front and three halls in a row, the middle hall built in Kasuga-zukuri style and the remaining two in Nagare-zukuri style

sen.j: 拝殿
sen.e: Worship hall
Worship hall
Worship hall

sen.j: 幣殿
sen.e: Votive offering hall
Votive offering hall
Votive offering hall

sen.j: 回廊（2棟）
sen.e: Corridor (building 2)
Corridor (building 2)
Corridor (two buildings)

sen.j: 附：透塀、釣燈篭4基（慶長9年・1604年および延享3年・1746年銘）
sen.e: Tsuketari (attachments, appurtenances): Sukibei (transparent fence), four hanging lanterns (inscribed 1604 and 1746)
Tsuketari (attachments, appurtenances): Sukibei (transparent fence), four hanging lanterns (inscribed 1604 and 1746)
Tsuketari (attachments, appurtenances): Sukibei (transparent fence), four hanging lanterns (inscribed 1604 and 1746)

sen.j: 木造天万栲幡千幡姫命（あめよろずたくはたちはたひめのみこと）坐像
sen.e: Wooden sitting statue of Ameyorozu Takuhatachihatahime no Mikoto
Wooden sitting statue of Ameyorozu Takuhatachihatahime no Mikoto
Wooden seated statue of Ameyorozu Takuhatachihatahime no Mikoto
sen.cmt: 坐像→統一リストの表記に修正しました。

sen.j: 近鉄吉野線吉野駅 (奈良県)より吉野ロープウェイ乗り換え「吉野山」下車、徒歩約1時間30分
sen.e: From Kintetsu Yoshino line Yoshino Station (Nara Prefecture) take the Yoshino ropeway to Yoshino-yama Station and walk 1.5 hours.
From Kintetsu Yoshino line Yoshino Station (Nara Prefecture) take the Yoshino ropeway to Yoshino-yama Station and walk 1.5 hours.
From the Kintetsu Yoshino Line Yoshino Station (Nara Prefecture) take the Yoshino ropeway to Yoshino-yama Station and walk 1.5 hours.
sen.cmt: the Kintetsu Yoshino Lineとしました。
